statement.p: From your answers to Problems 18, what you can conclude about the graphs of cubic polynomials? Consider the long-term behavior, x-intercepts, turning points, and inflection points.

answer.p: The graph of a cubic polynomial with a positive lead coefficient will have the same end behavior as the basic cubic, and a cubic with a negative lead coefficient will have the opposite end behavior. Each graph of a cubic polynomial has one, two, or three x-intercepts, it has two, one or no turning point, and it has exactly one inflection point.

assemblage.title: Division Algorithm for Polynomials
assemblage.p: If f(x) and g(x) are nonconstant polynomials with real coefficients, then there exist unique polynomials q(x) and r (x) such that f (x) = g(x)q(x) + r(x), where \text{deg } r(x) \lt \text{deg }g(x).

introduction.p: In Problems 5760, use polynomial division to divide f(x) by g(x) , and hence find the quotient, q(x) , and remainder, r(x) . (See Algebra Skills Refresher to review polynomial division.)

statement.p:
The remainder theorem states, If P(x) is a polynomial and a is any real number, there is a unique polynomial Q(x) such that P(x) = (x - a)Q(x) + P(a) Follow the steps below to prove the remainder theorem.
State the division algorithm applied to the polynomials P(x) and x-a.
What must be the degree of r(x) in this case?
Evaluate your expression from part (a) at x = a. What does this tell you about the remainder, r (x)?

li.p: If P(x) is a nonconstant polynomial with real coefficients and a is any real number, then there exist unique polynomials q(x) and r (x) such that P(x) = (x - a)q(x) + r (x) where \text{deg }r (x)\lt \text{deg }(x - a).
Zero
P(a) = (a - a)q(a) + r (a) = r (a). Because \text{deg }r(x) = 0 , r(x) is a constant. That constant value is P(a) , so P(x) = (x - a)q(x) + P(a).

statement.p:
Verify the remainder theorem for the following:
P(x) = x^3 - 4x^2 + 2x - 1, a = 2
P(x) = 3x^2 + x - 5, ~a = -3

Use the remainder theorem to prove the factor theorem, stated earlier in this section. You will need to justify two statements:
If P(a) = 0, show that x - a is a factor of P(x) .
If x-a is a factor of P(x), show that P(a)=0 .

li.p: By definition of a factor, if x-a is a factor of P(x) , then P(x) = (x - a)q(x), so P(x) =(x - a)q(x) + 0. The uniqueness guaranteed in the remainder theorem tells us that P(a) = 0.

The error in the approximation is the difference f (x) - p(x). We can reduce the error by using a polynomial of higher degree. The nth degree polynomial for approximating e^x is P_n(x) = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2!}x^2+\frac{1}{3!}x^3+ \cdots +\frac{1}{n!}x^n where n! = n(n - 1)(n - 2) \cdots 3 \cdot 2 \cdot 1.
